lg.l: THE first piece is a Letter from a reverend Divine to a Lady, giving an account of the imaginary murder of her husband, in a medicinal and chirurgical way: of which her ladyship intirely acquitted the person accused, by marrying him.

In his journey to D──bl──n he lighted at Ch──st──r, And there he grew fond of another man's wife:
Burst into her chamber, and would have caress'd her;But she valu'd her honour much more than her life.She bustled, and struggled, and made her escapeTo a room full of guests, for fear of a r──pe.
The D──n he pursued to recover his game; And now to attack her again, he prepares:
But the company stood in defence of the dame;They cudgell'd, and cuft him, and kick'd him down stairs.His D──nship was now in a damnable scrape;And this was no time for committing a r──pe.
To D──bl──n he comes, to the Bagnio he goes: And orders the landlord to bring him a whore:
No scruple came on him, his gown to expose;'Twas what all his life he had practis'd before:He made himself drunk with the juice of the grape;And got a good clap, but committed no r──pe.
The D──n, and his landlord, a jolly comrade, Resolv'd for a fortnight to swim in delight:
For why? they had both been brought up to the tradeOf drinking all day, and of whoring all night.My landlord was ready his D──nship to ape,In ev'ry debauch, but committing a r──pe.

I leave thee a guesser.But I only behold thee in 1John Atherton, bishop of Waterford, was executed at Dublin for bestiality, Dec. 5, 1640. `But he constantly denied the crime all along and with his lastbreath. And the chief witness against him, who was afterwards hanged, confessed at the gallows, That what he had sworn against the bishop was utterly false. And the whole kingdom of Ireland, especially the county wherein he lived, have ever since been, and are at this day, possessed with an opinion of his innocence. N. B. All who appeared against him came afterwards to disastrous deaths. Any person that hath a mind to be satisfied of the truth of this, may enquire at the Seneca's head near Somerset-house.' The preceding account was published in The Tatler NO. 120. Jan. 14, 1709. in answer to an impudent lie in the Preface to The Case of John Atherton, &c. published just before by E. Curll; wherein it was asserted, `That the bishop confessed the crime for which he suffered.'
